messageBody:
Michael Holly wrote:

> Listers please excuse the off topic nature.

Don't worry about it.

> Let me reply with some examples from the manufaturing industry.

Please do not compare software to manufacturing. They are not similar.
Instead, compare building software to product design and try again.
<snip />

> Now correct me if I am wrong (I'm sure you will) but better software
> development
> is about
>
> definable, documentable interfaces,
> modularization,
> testing ... repeatable testing,
> frameworks,
> patterns,
> components,
> automated documentation
> etc.

No. Better software is about delivering business value faster. The
things you list help us get there, but that list changes over time. They
are just today's tools.

> All of these concepts drive toward 'uniform' results. Even this newsgroup's
> purpose
> is about promotion of software that allows repeatable testing. Better
> software development
> is completely about bringing 'uniformity' to the process.

I don't like this, but I can't articulate an alternative. I'm working on it.

> If you have a definition of 'better software' then please supply it

Above. Software is better if it brings more value to my customer faster.
More value in the same time or same value faster would each also be better.

> This
> definition
> has to exist, otherwise, you have no standard to compare your latest project
> to validate
> that it is better. The feedback you are getting from this comparison will
> make *gasp* your
> process better!

XP is not about defining a process; it is about building up a toolkit
and learning how the tools work and when to use them. Judgment remains
the key ingredient and a defined process *encourages* me to *ignore* my
own judgment.
